# Scapular protraction

Scapular protraction is the movement of sliding your shoulder blades away from each other, moving them around your torso towards the front of your body. It is the opposite movement to [scapular retraction](scapprotraction.qmd).

The muscles involved in scapular protraction are the [serratus anterior](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK531457/#:~:text=The%20serratus%20anterior%20is%20a,inferior%20angle%20of%20the%20scapula.), [pectoralis major](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK525991/#:~:text=The%20pectoralis%20major%20is%20the,anterior%20wall%20of%20the%20axilla.), and [pectoralis minor](https://www.physio-pedia.com/Pectoralis_Minor?lang=en#:~:text=green).
